Einstein is also a strange choice since he spent only circa 10 years in America (surely a homegrown American physicist is more representative)

/* Assimilation and population changes */CiteCompletion, dates: 1, using [[Project:AWB|AWB]] (7004)
/* Politics */ More geographic specificity needed, move NYC up; introduce RS's terms and contextual link
/* Politics */ Sorry, return phrase 'or leftist'; prose technically incorrect without it. For example, in 1920 they voted Soc over the Dems by 2 to 1, per JVL ref
/* Politics */ result, did Democrat candidate win/lose?
/* Politics */ Remove OR 'bellweather' phrasing (unless there is a ref) and correct phrasing to that presented on table. What's left, however, is quite meaningless in light of refs already available
/* Politics */ Rephrase inclusion of pro-Zionist planks in '44 and '48
/* Politics */ Re-write 40s elections for inclusion of 3rd-party candidate
Actually, it is 3 of 12 (Humphrey as well) and 2 of last 3, making it questionable for second part of sentence.
OR implies that this was a major factor in Jewish voting, when based on the numbers, it clearly was not.
/* Politics */ Reinstate 50 years of ref'd Jewish voting habits as prose. The new table is insufficient
Liberal Party is almost complete overlap with Democrats, and there were Republicans (Jacob Javitz) who were Liberal. Misleading and definitely almost 0% accurate in last 50 years.
"leftist" includes the American Labor Party, & Liberal Party -- for which many New York Jews voted
"Leftist" colloquially implies socialist/communist, which is not supported. Democrat covers left of center adequately.
